class="card-content"> <p data-page="1">Although Facebook Inc. doesn’t sell robots, its researchers use plenty of them — and the company said its machines are getting a lot smarter a lot faster.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>The social media giant <a href="https://ai.facebook.com/blog/advancing-ai-by-teaching-robots-to-learn/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">announced Friday</a> that its engineers, working with computer scientists from New York University, have reduced the time it takes to teach a robotic arm how to grasp objects to tens of tries, rather than hundreds or thousands.</p> </div></div> <div class="mobile-dfp inline-ad hidden-desktop" data-inline-ad-count="1" style=""> <div class="wrapper clearfix full pb-feature pb-layout-item pb-f-ads-dfp" data-pb-name="DFP Ad" data-pb-curated="curated" id="fXyWnc2XYul2rr"> <div class="pb-ad pb-ad-prod ad-300x250 hidden-desktop relative" style=""> <div class="ad-caption-text align-center uppercase">Advertisement</div> <div id="tech_blog_1409" class="hidden" style=""> </div> </div>  </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>It may seem like a tangential development for the social media giant, but advancements in robotics can lead to improvements in other forms of machine learning, smartening the software Facebook has begun to use to spot harmful or unfavorable behavior of users on the social network.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>The company has been under increasing pressure to use artificial intelligence to police extremist violence, hate speech and misinformation on its platform. It has said that it is making progress but that systems that can reliably block such content without human intervention are still years away.</p> </div></div> <div class="desktop-nativo mobile-yieldmo inline-ad" data-inline-ad-count="2" style=""> <span class="hidden-desktop" style=""> <div class="wrapper clearfix col pb-feature pb-layout-item pb-f-ads-yieldmo" data-pb-name="Yieldmo Ad" data-pb-curated="curated" id=""> </div></span> <span class="hidden-mobile"><div class="wrapper clearfix full pb-feature pb-layout-item pb-f-ads-nativo" data-pb-name="Nativo Ad" data-pb-curated="curated" id="fmtiIL1aZul2rr"> <div class="hidden-mobile"> <div id="10911" data-nativo-id-desktop="1081094" class="desktop-nativo-ad trb_ar_nt"></div> </div> </div></span> </div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>“The great thing about robotics is that it takes place in real time, in the real world,” Antoine Bordes, co-managing director of the company’s artificial intelligence research labs, said in an interview last week in Paris.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>He contrasted this to research that taught AI to master games, such as chess or Go, which can be run at superhuman speeds enabling a software agent to learn from playing millions of games against itself in a period of a few weeks. Many contemporary AI methods are extremely data-hungry, requiring thousands or millions of labeled examples to learn from — or thousands or millions of attempts in a simulated environment — to equal or exceed human performance.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>Facebook began working on robots in the last year because it forced researchers to think creatively about how to make machine learning more efficient, Bordes said, but added that the company has no plans to commercialize its robots any time soon.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>In addition to the robotic arm, Facebook has experimented with finding ways for a six-legged robot to teach itself how to walk. It said it eventually hoped to reduce the time needed to train such a skill to hours instead of days or weeks.</p> </div></div> <div class="mobile-nativo inline-ad hidden-desktop" data-inline-ad-count="3" style=""> <div class="wrapper clearfix full pb-feature pb-layout-item pb-f-ads-nativo" data-pb-name="Nativo Ad" data-pb-curated="curated" id="fu7SJh2jZul2rr"> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>With computer scientists from UC Berkeley, Facebook has experimented with having robots learn about their world through tactile sensors that give them “a sense of touch” rather than relying solely on computer vision.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item"> <div class="card-content"> <p>Yann LeCun, Facebook’s chief AI scientist, said in an interview Friday that the company’s researchers had a responsibility to “see around corners” to where technology might be heading. If robots do eventually become a popular consumer good and Facebook decides to sell them, he said, the company would need to have experts already on staff.</p> </div></div> <div data-type="text" class="card collection-item card-border-bottom card-border-bottom-thick card-border-bottom-dark"> <div class="card-content"> <p>“You’ve got to start early,” he said. “It’s not just something you can jump into when it picks up.”</p> <div class="spaced spaced-md spaced-bottom hidden-mobile"></div> <div class="spaced spaced-sm spaced-bottom hidden-desktop hidden-tablet" style=""></div> </div></div> </div> </div> <div class="wrapper clearfix spaced spaced-none full pb-feature pb-layout-item pb-f-global-newsletter-promo" data-pb-name="Newsletter Promo Card" data-pb-curated="curated" id="f0Z0PMYXrdhThr"> <div class="card card-border-bottom card-border-bottom-thick"> <div class="card-content flex-grid"> <div class="flex-container-row col col-desktop-6 col-tablet-6 col-mobile-6"> <div class="flex-grid justify-center"> <div class="col col-desktop-6 col-tablet-6 col-mobile-6"> <div class="flex-container-row"> <div class="flex-container-column"> <div class="newsletter-promo-image"> <figure class=""> <div class="left-element image-xs img-container aspect-ratio-1x1"> <img style="height: 72px; width: 72px; background: #000"> </div> </figure> </div> </div> <div class="flex-container-column flex-fill"> <div class="newsletter-promo-text"> <div> <h6 class="flex capitalized">California Inc.
